newsitem.title: USA: Dow Jones family member resigns post.
newsitem.headline: Dow Jones family member resigns post.

text.p: William Cox III, a member of the family that controls Dow Jones & Co. Inc., has resigned from his job at the media company, a Dow Jones spokesman said Friday.
Most recently, Cox was managing Dow Jones' global stock indexes, spokesman Sanford Jacobs said.

Dow Jones, which supplies business news and information and publishes the Wall Street Journal, received a letter from Cox saying he was leaving the company, where he had worked for 18 years, Jacobs said.
Jacobs said he could not divulge reasons given by Cox for his departure.
Cox and a cousin, Elisabeth Goth, have made headlines in recent weeks over their stated disappointment with the New York-based company's direction and the value of its stock.
Other family members, including Cox's father, have said they support Dow Jones management.

Dow Jones' stock took a hit in late January after the company reported it would spend $650 million to expand and revitalise its Telerate financial information services unit. On the day of that announcement, the company's stock fell $4.50 to $36.375.
Dow Jones stock rose 37.5 cents to $39.625 on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday.

Cox, 41, whose father William Cox Jr. is on the board of directors, said he resigned from the company for a variety of reasons, but still plans to pursue efforts to make Dow Jones "There's a lot of value at Dow Jones, but I think it has to be unlocked," Cox said in an interview. He said he had not "deviated at all" from his quest to increase shareholder value at Dow Jones.
But he said the overriding reasons he decided to leave the company are "personal," as well as financial, maintaining he could make three times as much elsewhere.
"I've got a lot of offers," Cox said, declining to name his options.
Cox said he gave two weeks' notice. His last day is Feb. 21 at Dow Jones.
